editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

Foxes Actes and Monumentes, I vnderÅ¿taÌd as they were printed the yere 1563 by Iohn Day. Bezaes notes vpon the new teÅ¿tament I meane as they were printed at Geneua, the yere 1556. Next, whereas Å¿ome are offended with vs, for that in writing or Å¿peaking of them,Of the name, ProteÅ¿tants and Sacramentaries. we vÅ¿e the names of Sacramentaries, Zuinglians or CaluiniÅ¿tes, Puritanes, and Parlament ProteÅ¿tantes, which they Å¿ay are odious nicknames found out of vs,Ful. in the AnÅ¿were to M. Martins preface. pa. 17. and therefore one of their writers of late chargeth vs in Å¿peaking of them to vÅ¿e no other names then ChriÅ¿tians and Catholikes: for our diÅ¿charge herein thus much I muÅ¿t Å¿ignifie vnto thee, that if ether truth & learning would beare vs vÅ¿ing Å¿uch termes as they require, or any reader ether Catholike or ProteÅ¿tant vnderÅ¿tand vs, we would moÅ¿t gladly for loue of the truth and their contentation Å¿o Å¿peake and write. But now conÅ¿ider thou how intolerably Å¿uch Å¿peaches would Å¿ouÌd in the eares of any indifferent reader. I haue occaÅ¿ion Å¿ometimes to produce Luther

Whitgift againÅ¿t the Puritanes, (for Å¿o he calleth them) Å¿ometimes the Puritanes againÅ¿t him and Å¿uch as maintaine the CoÌmunion booke and religion of England, in Å¿uch Å¿ort and Å¿o far forth as is approued by Acte of parlament. Now citing theÅ¿e writers how can we cite them without a lie, if we cited them in other wordes then themÅ¿elues vÅ¿e? If I Å¿aid Luther in his booke againÅ¿t the fanatical Å¿pirites of the ChriÅ¿tians & Catholikes, or, D. VVhitg. in his DefenÅ¿e againÅ¿t the ChriÅ¿tians and Catholikes, who could ether perceaue what I meant, or who would not iudge that I did them great iniury in making them to write againÅ¿t ChriÅ¿tians, which none do but Iewes & Turkes, or againÅ¿t Catholikes vvhich none do but heretikes and ApoÅ¿tataes. And marueil it is, that the name of ProteÅ¿taÌtes is novv grovven into Å¿o great diÅ¿like, vvhich hitherto hath bene Å¿o magnified in bookes, pulpits, and ordinarie phraÅ¿e of talke, and vvhich M.Pag. 653. & 1717. But the truth is, thoÅ¿e that profeÅ¿Å¿e the EngliÅ¿h faith and religion,ThoÅ¿e that profeÅ¿Å¿e the EngliÅ¿h religion, are not Catholikes. ether haue no name at al to be knovven by but the common name of heretikes, vvhich is to general, and vvould be to odious, or their moÅ¿t propre name is Zuinglians or Sacramentaries. For to cal them Catholikes and ChriÅ¿tians, beÅ¿ides that it is falÅ¿e and ridiculous, and may vvith like probabilitie be chalenged of euery other kind of Å¿ecte, Lutheran,Brentius et Lutherani paÅ¿sim. Brentian, Arrian, Puritan, beÅ¿ides that their greateÅ¿t vvriters mocke and Å¿corne at the name Catholike as PopiÅ¿h and Å¿uperÅ¿titious, beÅ¿ides this I Å¿ay, it expreÅ¿Å¿eth not that particular religion, in vvhich they differre from the reÅ¿t of the ChriÅ¿tian vvorld, for vvhich vve vvrite againÅ¿t them, and for vvhich the Lutheranes oppoÅ¿e theÌ Å¿elues againÅ¿t them, and vvhich by their name ought Å¿pecially to be Å¿ignified.

Nor ProteÅ¿tants.The name of ProteÅ¿tantes, which commonly they vÅ¿urpe, is wrongfully chalenged of them, as which duely &
only belongeth to the Lutheranes,Sleidan. li. 6 fol. 102.101.109. who for oppoÅ¿ing them Å¿elues againÅ¿t the decrees of the Empyre & Emperour touching Catholike religion, and proteÅ¿ting that they would Å¿tand in defence of their owne, according to the ConfeÅ¿sion exhibited at AuÅ¿purg, were firÅ¿t for their Å¿o doing and proteÅ¿ting, named ProteÅ¿tantes, as much to Å¿ay, as men that Å¿tood and proteÅ¿ted againÅ¿t the Catholike faith for their priuate, in Å¿uch Å¿ort as hath bene noted. And briefly, that no other name can be duely applied vnto them beÅ¿ides the name of Zuinglians, by this reaÅ¿on it may playnely appeare.ThoÅ¿e of the EngliÅ¿h fayth, are moÅ¿t properly called Zuinglians, or Sacramentaries. When they brake from the reÅ¿t of the ChriÅ¿tian vvorld, vvhich they Å¿ay vvas couered vvith palpable darkenes, and betooke them Å¿elues to that light of the goÅ¿pel, vvhereof novv they Å¿o much brag and boaÅ¿t, vvho vvas their maiÅ¿ter, ringleader, and ApoÅ¿tle therein, but Huldericus Zuinglius? of their EngliÅ¿h church.Apol. EccleÅ¿iae Anglicanae. d. â¢ . In the middeÅ¿t of that darknes (Å¿ay they) thoÅ¿e most excellent men, Martin Luther, and Hulderike Zuinglius Å¿ent from God to illuminate the vvhole vvorld, first came to the GoÅ¿pel. MiÅ¿si Ã Deo ad illustrandum terrarum orbem, primuÌ acceÅ¿Å¿erunt ad Euangelium. Now whereas them Å¿elues & al other, name thoÅ¿e goÅ¿pellers which folow Luthers Å¿enÅ¿e and interpretation, by the name of Lutherans, they vvho prefer Zuinglius before Luther, and profeÅ¿Å¿e them Å¿elues to haue receaued the light of the GoÅ¿pel from him, hovv Å¿hould they be called but Zuinglians? not only for like reaÅ¿on, vvhich hath bene vÅ¿ed in al times and ages from the firÅ¿t beginning of the primitiue Church, vvhere the SectemaiÅ¿ters haue geuen appellation to their after-commers, as in Marcion, Valentinus, Carpocrates, Nouatus & the reÅ¿t, but much more and eÅ¿pecially becauÅ¿e them Å¿elues chalenge him for their maiÅ¿ter in their particular faith and religion. And therefore it can not be avoided, but as Luthers Å¿cholers, are called Lutherans, Å¿o Zuinglius diÅ¿ciples ought of like right to be called Zuinglians.

And to end this quarel, our aduerÅ¿aries
them Å¿elues who haue written of theÅ¿e matters, Å¿hal Å¿erue to quite vs of al fault. M. Fox in his Å¿torie when Å¿oeuer he Å¿peaketh of that Å¿ect vvhich him Å¿elf beÅ¿t-liked,

Touching any other fault, I Å¿hal be ready ether to defeÌd it, or to correct it. to correct it, if it be noted againÅ¿t me iuÅ¿tly, to defend it if it be obiected vndeÅ¿eruedly. & this I proteÅ¿t not only in words, as coÌmonly do al ProteÅ¿tantes, but in Å¿implicitie of truth, as meaning to performe the Å¿ame.
